bioghist.p: Youth Liberation was an organization founded in 1971 by fifteen-year-old Keith Hefner and other Ann Arbor teenagers. Its central aims included student control of education, the free development of youth culture, and an end to discrimination against youth, with related emphases on gay rights for young people, environmentalism, and an end to the Vietnam War. Youth Liberation served as a principal informational and organizational hub for a host of similar efforts around the country, and also allied with older radicals in Ann Arbor- and Detroit-area organizations such as the White Panther Party and the Human Rights Party. The group's publications arm, the Youth Liberation Press, began in 1969 as a separate entity known as the High School Independent Press, based in Chicago, Illinois. After a short stint from 1970-1972 in Houston, Texas, where the press began publishing FPS, a news service for youth, the press moved to Ann Arbor and merged with Youth Liberation of Ann Arbor. In addition to FPS, the press put out several collections of essays in book and pamphlet format. Youth Liberation functioned from Spring 1970 to Fall 1979, a when a crucial member departed for New York City.

scopecontent.p: The collection includes both administrative records and published materials. Administrative records of Youth Liberation and CHIPS include letters to readers, reader and student newspaper questionnaires, mailing lists, and correspondence from creators of student newspapers. The collection contains number of issues of FPS, as well as text copy and reference materials for articles in FPS. The collection also includes issues of many high school underground newspapers and other youth publications (1970-1981). Titles include Youth Awareness Press, Weekly Reefer, School Break, and the 5% Press.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
